awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of a clumped isotope gas-source isotope-ratio mass spectrometer and carbonate device for inclusive research and education at the University of Washington
awd_abstract_narration:
The acquisition of a mass spectrometer and sample preparation equipment will be used to advance research and education in diverse fields of Earth-system science including geology, paleoclimate, and biological and ocean sciences. The new instrumentation will greatly enhance analytical capabilities in new geochemistry methods at the University of Washington (UW) to precisely measure the temperature and chemistry of carbonate minerals when formed in soils, lakes, oceans, fault zones, hydrothermal systems, and laboratory experiments. The temperature estimates and cutting-edge chemical analyses will support research on modern and ancient environments to study Earth’s climate system, past atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations, the origin of landforms like the Colorado Plateau, and geologic drivers of biodiversity. Analyses of corals and shelled organisms will support environmental and marine sciences research relevant to ecology, physiology, and biochemistry. The instrumentation will also enable analysis of minerals formed in fault zones and hydrothermal systems to study the interactions of sub-surface fluids and faulting, ancient earthquakes, and chemical reactions relevant to ore deposits, critical metals, and carbon dioxide sequestration. The research and educational opportunities provided by this instrument acquisition will advance trans-disciplinary research and education at UW and in the Earth science community. The award will advance equity in undergraduate laboratory training and research through direct support of underrepresented minority students and broad dissemination of best practices for inclusive engagement with undergraduates. The instrument acquisition will substantially enhance infrastructure for essential Earth sciences research and education and contribute to technological innovation, societally-relevant scientific discovery, and building diverse STEM talent. 

This award supports the acquisition and installation of a new carbonate sample preparation device and high-precision gas-source isotope-ratio mass spectrometer (IRMS) to measure clumped isotopologues of CO2 at UW, to advance interdisciplinary research in tectonics, paleoclimate, geochemistry, and other Earth-science disciplines. The acquisition of the IRMS and sample preparation system will enable rapid, high-precision complete stable isotopic analysis (masses 44 - 49 inclusive) of small (<0.5 mg) carbonate samples for a wide range of ongoing and new research including novel applications of dual-clumped isotope analysis, and free up existing instrumentation to substantially increase capacity for novel triple-oxygen-isotope analyses. The system will replace 1) an off-line custom preparation system for large (8-10 mg) carbonate samples, 2) an existing IRMS with modified collector for traditional clumped (mass 47 excess) work acquired with NSF funding in 2012, both of which will be optimized to support carbonate oxygen-17 excess analyses; and 3) replace ageing instrumentation that no longer provides reliable conventional carbonate bulk stable isotope data. In this way, the proposed instrument acquisition will be leveraged to expand capabilities for carbonate oxygen-17 excess analysis, traditional bulk stable isotope analyses, and enable new high-precision dual clumped isotope (47 and 48 excess) analyses of small samples, substantially benefitting hundreds of Earth-science researchers and students. The proposed research is tightly integrated with education and outreach. The project will increase undergraduate geoscience lab opportunities through 1) direct support for student technical training and research in partnership with a cohort program for underrepresented minority undergraduates, and 2) national dissemination of research-based practices for enhancing belonging, accessibility, justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion in undergraduate geoscience laboratory research and training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project enabled the acquisition and installation of a state-of-the-art clumped isotope mass spectrometer and carbonate preparation device at the University of Washington. This new instrumentation significantly enhances research and education in Earth sciences, expanding capabilities for high-precision stable isotope analyses of carbonate minerals. These advancements support a wide range of scientific disciplines, including paleoclimate reconstruction, geochemistry, tectonics, and biogeochemistry.

Clumped isotope geochemistry is a cutting-edge technique that allows scientists to reconstruct past temperatures, environmental conditions, and biological and geochemical processes. Unlike traditional isotope methods, which infer temperature based on oxygen isotope ratios and assumed water compositions, clumped isotope analysis directly measures how heavy, rare isotopes of carbon and oxygen "clump" together in carbonate minerals--a process governed by temperature. This approach provides a more direct, thermometer-like record of the conditions under which carbonates formed.

Clumped isotope geochemistry is transforming fields from paleoclimate and tectonics to biogeochemistry. It allows us to quantify the temperatures of ancient oceans, lakes, and soil environments that shaped Earth's history. By applying this method to fossilized shells, stalagmites, and ancient soils, we can better understand ice age cycles, the evolution of climate-sensitive ecosystems, and carbon cycling over geologic time. The method is also applied to fault zones, geothermal fields, hydrocarbon-producing basins, and ore deposits to help us understand earthquake hazards and energy and mineral resources. 

The new Nu Perspective gas-source isotope-ratio mass spectrometer with NuCarb sample preparation system enables high-precision measurement of multiple isotopic signals, including Δ47, Δ48, δ18O, and δ13C, from small carbonate samples. By enabling both Δ47 and novel Δ48 clumped isotope measurements, the new system enables frontier applications in detecting non-equilibrium chemical reactions, crucial for understanding natural processes and potential industrial applications like carbon capture. Additionally, the new instrumentation increases total throughput in the lab, allowing us to significantly expand analytical method development and novel triple-oxygen-isotope applications using pre-existing equipment. These capabilities provide deeper insights into climate dynamics, landscape evolution, and Earth's geochemical processes.

The UW team successfully installed, tested, calibrated, and optimized the system. Custom software was developed to optimize analysis and enhance quality control, and data processing was structured to comply with FAIR principles, ensuring research is Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable. Method development and calibration against international standards demonstrated excellent accuracy and precision, confirmed by interlaboratory comparison tests.

Since installation, the new instrumentation has supported over 20 independent research projects and numerous NSF-funded studies, including paleo-CO2 reconstructions within the CO2PIP consortium. Researchers from multiple institutions--including the University of Texas at Austin, Western Washington University, Brigham Young University, the University of California at Davis, and San Diego State University--have accessed the University of Washington system for their work. Demand remains high, with a six-month backlog for instrument access and expanding external collaborations. 

Beyond research, this project has strengthened education and workforce development by training students and researchers in advanced analytical techniques. The project lead published a review article and companion handbook for teaching clumped isotope geochemistry, designed university curriculum, and led an international short course on the topic. Method development and research phases of the project offered hands-on training to 3 faculty, 1 research scientist, 3 postdoctoral researchers, 6 undergraduates, and 12 graduate students. Many trainees presented findings at conferences and pursued graduate studies or geoscience careers. Undergraduate STEM Futures Fellows gained technical training, laboratory experience, and mentorship to strengthen the STEM workforce.

By integrating cutting-edge instrumentation and research with inclusive educational practices, this award has expanded both scientific discovery and student engagement in geoscience research. These outcomes align with NSF's mission to advance societally relevant scientific knowledge and cultivate the next generation of STEM professionals. The research capabilities enabled by this award will continue to benefit Earth science communities for years to come.
